sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: You tell me, she and Romulus are both
To die, Condemn'd by Tatius for the Rape;
But notwithstanding, if I'le prevail with him
To quit Hersilia to your love, you'l give
Him Liberty, and me my Fort again.—

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Most willingly.

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: I think you said you never lov'd the Treason
But for Hersilia's sake. That 'twas my Daughter
Betray'd the Gate, for which alone you hate her,
And fain would give it back on these conditions—

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Most true.

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: No, hate my Daughter still, hate her as much
As I do; It is the only act of all thy Life,
That shews thee good or brave: Know thou most vile
Of all the Sabines, that the King of Rome
Has not so poor Soul, but he had rather
Lose twenty thousands lives, than but one thought
(The least of all his thoughts) for his Hersilia.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: And will you not perswade him?

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: Yes: Where he not already fixt I would
Perswade him, and use all means, all Arguments
To settle him in such a Resolution.—
'Tis well for thee, I am thy Prisoner, Curtius:
Had I my Liberty, and Sword again
I'de answer in another phrase, and tell
Thy heart, what 'tis to tempt a Roman to
So base an action.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Are you so brave; Ho there without; who waits
Take him and guard him strictly, on your lives
Let him not speak to any, nor be seen.
I'me at a loss, my best design is blasted,
Yet I'le not give it o're, Hersilia's Love
Has joyes enough to recompence, a thousand crosses.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Yonder's my Captain, Sir, at leisure too,
But you must leave your Sword with me.

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: Take it.—
Hail to the Noble Curtius, if you be he?
I have affiars that touch you very nearly.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I am the man, if they concern my life;
Speak boldly.

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: They do, and what's more near, your love.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Speak softly, Boy. The very name of love
Hath something in't so sacred, it requires
A private ear and ought not to be heard
By any unconcern'd; the profane vulgar.
Withdraw, and suffer none whoever, to
Approach this way, till I give notice.

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: It is indeed a mighty secret Sir,
And we can't be too private.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: True Boy,—
Now speak.

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: I am sent hither from the fam'd Sybilla—

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: About my Love? Ay, Ay, I do not doubt it.
'Tis such a strong and violent passion, Boy,
The Gods may well take notice of it.
What says the Prophetess? Did she not name
Hersilia in the Message? If she did not,
O never speak it to me; all other words
Are discords in my ear.

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: She did, she did,
She nam'd the sweet Hersilia often,
And said,— But first, see my Credentials, Curtius.—
Look Sir, this is her hand, and this; no, this—
sp.stage: She gives him a Letter, and as he is opening it to read, she comes up, and looking over his left Shoulder, as if she would instruct him in something, whips out his Sword.
sp.l: Turn hither Monster, and behold thy Hell,
Before you feel the flames,— I am Tarpeia.—
Nay stir not, or by all the Gods, and all
The Devils, like thy self, I'le nail thee to
The ground: tho I am a Woman, yet I am
Inspir'd with all the force and fury now of twenty men.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: It is the very she;
What a dull beast was I not to suspect
That face! my Love transported me to ruine.

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: Tremble, and hear me thou inhumane Villain.
I come prepar'd to take a full revenge
For all my slighted Love, my ruin'd honour,
For Romulus, my Country, and my Father.
I value not my life, when I have thine
I'le give mine freely up to any torment.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: How have I wrong'd you, Madam? You know too well,
Our passion's not at our own choice, if fate
Has pointed your love this way, mine to another,
It is your fate has wrong'd you, and not I.

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: Unheard of impudence! face of a Devil!
Can you say this to me? To me who have
Betray'd my King, my Country, Father, All,
For thou perfidious wretch? 'Tis not thy Love
I value now, but seek for my lost honour:—
Didst thou not swear, thy Love was free? and by
That specious bait tempt me to be a Devil?
Give me my faith again I owe my Country:
Give me again my Innocence, false man,
Make me no traytor.— O it can not be!
My names all over fully'd, black, black, as Hell,—
But I will wash it in thy blood: I'le search
The fountain of thy veins, suck thy hearts blood,
Then knaw the flesh into a thousand peices,
And grieve the diet will not last for ever.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Where are my Guards? O that they knew my danger!
Will no kind Demon tell 'em.— Ho! without.

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: Nay if you open, Hell-hound, then have at thee.

div.stage: [Makes at him, he strives to defend himself, but is wounded.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Yet spare my life and I will pardon all.
I'le Love thee too, give back the Fort and Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: Abhorred Creature! no: I now hate more
Than I e're lov'd, tho I lov'd more than any.
Wert thou more suppliant at my feet, than I
Too lately was at thine, I'd spurn at thy
Petitions, thus; and be more cruel,
If it were possible, than thou wer't, Devil.
As for the Fort, I'le quickly take that back.
But first thy life.—

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: To Armes, to Armes: Where are you Curtius?
Captain to Armes, to Armes, we are surpriz'd.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Make hast and break the door.

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: I'le open first a door to thy false heart.
[Curtius closes Tarp. and as they are striving, the Guard enter.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Ha! Curtius, unarm'd and wounded? See the young Traytor.
Oh Murderous Villain!—

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Forbear, it is a Woman,—

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: O Sir, the Forts in danger,— the Romans headed
By their Hostilius, pour like a torrent on us.
We want your Countenance and conduct.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I am much wounded, but I think none mortal:
On to the danger,—
Despised thing, false both to Rome and me,
Make use of these few minutes I'le but secure
My Guard, at my return expect
The due reward which all thy Treasons Merit.

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: Yes, I will use the time— I bleed: Tis nothing,
The sight does but incourage me to action.
O that I had a Sword! I'le to the assault
While all is in Confusion, I cannot miss
A weapon on the place: My Country calls;
My help, though weak▪ will yet assist her something.
Could I die fighting for her, I were happy.
When life's a burthen, all our fortune cross,
To lose it Nobly then; how sweet's the loss?

div.head: SCENE I. The Fort

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: THE Fort is ours again: But we have strangely
Mist the Commander.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Sabinus Curtius, Sir, when he perceived
All past Redemption, with some few Officers,
Forced their way through us, and fled safely over
To their own Camp: the rest are Prisoners.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: My little Rival there, and bloody too?
I see he's more a Man than I expected,
Know you that Boy?

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: I found him, Sir, amidst the thickest danger,
Fighting on our side, fiercely, till spent with loss
Of blood, a rough old Sabine, had seiz'd
And wou'd have kill the fainting Youth, when I
Stept in and saved him.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: It was well done, and I'le reward you for it:
All favour's due to such an early Courage.—
Thou art a Gallant Boy, and I repent
I chid thee lately, prithee reveal thy Name,
That we may know, to whom we give our praises.

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: It is not worth your knowledge, brave Hostilius,
My Name's dishonourable, worse than none,
Unless I get a Name that's worth the speaking
I beg to die unknown.—

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: See Sir, the Royal Prisoners come to meet you,

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Do we see our Hostilius once again?
I cannot say, in which I am most happy,
To see my friend restored, or Liberty.—
O, my Hersilia, now we cannot die;
This world is too inviting: All our joyes
Return, and we shall now be Gods in Rome.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: The happiness is mine, blessed am I,
That I am pointed out to serve my King,
My best of Friends, and (whom I blush to name,)
The sweet Hersilia: It is a glorious office!
The very boys have so much sense of Honour;
And think it Heaven to die in such a cause.
This youth endeavour'd it as well as I.

sp.speaker: Sp. Tarp.
sp.l: Ha! my Daughter in disguise! O thou shame
Of Roman Maids. Take this reward of Treason—

div.stage: [Draws and runs at her, Hostilius steps between.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Hold! What means the Mad-man? Wou'd you reward
With death, him, who still bleeds from all these wounds
Received so lately in his Countries quarrel?

sp.speaker: Sp. Tarp.
sp.l: Persist not in an Errour, good Hostilius,
This is no Boy, but my accursed Daughter,—
With-hold me not, I have a Parents Right,
And claim to take her life at my own freedom.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: That Argument I never will allow of,
'Twas used against Hersilia.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I am amazed! can any woman have,
A Soul so Masculine?

sp.speaker: Sp. Tarp.
sp.l: Say rather, so degenerate, and full of horrour,
Since this is that false Devil that betray'd
The Fort, her King, and Father, to the Sabines.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: This is all Riddle, how cou'd she betray
Her Prince, who has expos'd her life to save him.
I must examine this more strictly,—

div.stage: Romulus goes over, and discourses with Tarpeia, and her Father, while Hostilius and Hersilia come forward.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: Hostilius you have merited from me so highly
In freeing my dear Lord, from instant death,
That I should be confounded much, to make
A due acknowledgment of such a service:
Did I not know of a reward will please you.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I'me stupifi'd. I know not what to answer.
I dare not look: I dare not trust, my eyes
With the dear object.—

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: Do you not mind me Sir, Why do you look
Another way?— Yours merits are too modest.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: In vain I guard my eyes: In vain I keep
That Post secure: My ear, my ear betrays me.—
Too much reward it is already, Madam,
For me to hear such words from fair Hersilia.
What man can merit such kind words, and live?
If I had dyed in such a cause, as this,
Perhaps the sweet Hersilia might have then
Applauded me with better Justice.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: No more of this.—
As soon as we return back to the Pallace
Be you in the Court Garden:
I'le meet you there in the close Mirtle-walk,
And then confer, the dear reward I mention.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I dare not understand her meaning.—
Now, now, Hostilius, summon all thy vertue,
Call all thy Honour to thy help, for all
Is much too little.—

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: So brave an act, after so base a Treason
I never knew the same hand guilty of.

sp.speaker: Sp. Tarp.
sp.l: I cannot yet receive her for my Daughter,
The stain of Treason is indelible,
Nor has she purg'd her Crime by her late service.
Since she was bound to that, tho she had ne're
Offended.— She ought to die.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Spurius Tarpeius, no: You give your Prince
Dishonourable Counsel. Shou'd I forget
Her wounds still bleeding? Ingratitude's in me
Almost as great a blemish as her Treason.

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: If you intend me any favour Sir?
If I have merited in my last action?
Do as my Father urges. Take my life:
Since I mist that of Curtius, mines a Burden,
A shame, a Torment to me. Had I but
Recover'd my lost Honour: Had not my
Revenge, my Glory, my intended service
Been all defeated by Hostilius coming,
I then cou'd have endured to live,
Or any fate, life had not been uneasie.—
If you'l not give me death as a reward?
If I appear to ask too great a Boon?
Confer it as a Punishment for Treason.
If neither way I can have what I beg:
Sullen, and out of favour with my fortune,
I'le try to give my self what you deny me.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: Will you, Tarpeia, stand to my decission?

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: With all my Soul: I'me sure the sweet Hersilia
Will give me what I ask, a speedy death;
Since by my act, she and her Romulus
Were both so very near it.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: Then, with my dear Lords leave, this is my Sentence.
Tarpeia, you shall live: And yet to please you,
I will inflict a Civil death, you shall,
During your life, be a devoted Recluse,
A Vestal, ever serving at the Altar,
And Sacrifice for us whom you have wrong'd.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Now to Mount Palatine: Come my Captive Queen,
And change a Prison, for a Court, Joys tast
More sweet, when relisht by afflictions past

div.stage: Tarpeia alone, two of the Guards at a distance.

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: A Nun! O no: The thought is worse than death.
Can I, I who have felt so many fires
In my own breast, whose heart has burnt so long
In Love and fury, that I am now all ashes?
Can I—
Tamely submit to guard the Vestal Flames?
Pardon me Goddess; Pardon me Hersilia;
I have not Soul enough to live at ease.—
O Earth, Earth, Earth! Take me to your Embraces.
Why shou'd I use the air? My Soul's all fled,
Spent and evaporate in fruitless Passion.
There's nothing left to poor Tarpeia now
But a base fordid Lump of worthless mould.
Colour, that fleeting Summer shade, and all
That little Beauty I once had, has left me:
Like a false dream, 'tis vanisht in a moment.
Yet I have still a name remains: Ah, less
Then nothing! unless it cou'd survive with Glory.
To cleanse thy spoted name, die then, Tarpeia;
Nothing but death can give a life to fame.
(Rising) Ha! my Sorrows are betray'd:— Unmanner'd Villains,
Do you stay here as Spies upon my action?

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: We wait here, Madam, by the Kings Command:
Our duty is to see you safely lodged
In Vesta's Temple.—

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: Forbear: And know your distance, base Plebeians;
I have not leasure yet to be Religious.—
O! I am much opprest: Too much black blood
Lies heavy at my heart, and drowns my Spirits.
But I will give it vent.— Stay, I have here,
Full on my breast, a Sabine wound imperfect.
What Curtius Soldiers have begun, I'le finish:
Through the same Orifice I'le send my steel
Into that wound which Curtius gave my heart.
O loved and hated Name! Since he refused
The Joys of Love, thus I'le remove the pains.

sp.speaker: 1. Guard.
sp.l: O she has kill'd her self! the mad Virago
Has out done all her former actions, here.
Call for more help.—

sp.speaker: 2. Guard.
sp.l: Help, there within; Tarpeia bleeds to death!

sp.speaker: Sp. Tarp.
sp.l: What means this suddain out-cry? Ha!
Is still Tarpeia here? My shame still here? Not yet a Vestal?

sp.speaker: 1. Guard.
sp.l: O Sir, behold your Daughter lies expiring:
Wild with her discontents, from her own Sword
She took that death which you so much desired,
And Romulus denyed.

sp.speaker: Sp. Tarp.
sp.l: She bleeds: Kind Heavens! from her own hand she bleeds.
O truly Roman! Let me embrace my Daughter:
I am not now ashamed to be her Father.

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: Forgive me Sir, the scandal I have given
Both to my Parents, and my dearer Country.
I am unworthy to be called a Roman.
A Roman is no Traytor! A Roman's brave,
Just, true, and of a mind above Corruption.
But I have been so false I cannot speak it.
The Soul of my good name's long since expired,
And why shou'd I survive?

sp.speaker: Sp. Tarp.
sp.l: True, true, my lovely Daughter! O thou art now
In this last ebb of life, more fair than ever.
Others may think thy former beauty fadeing,
Languid, and dying-pale as a cropt Lilly;
To me the Roses of thy Cheeks still flourish,
Fresh as the blooming Spring, sweet as the East:
These closing eyes are real Jewels now;
Poetick fury cannot make 'em brighter.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: O tell me, Sir, truly, as you are noble.
Do not dissemble: Have I redeem'd my Crime,
And with my blood cleans'd the foul stains of Treason?

sp.speaker: Sp. Tar.
sp.l: Believe me then,—
Thou art all white again, my dear Tarpeia;
This glorious Act restores thy innocence,
And from this hour, thou art new born to me
A spotless Roman Virgin.

sp.speaker: Tar.
sp.l: It is enough! Have I all this for dying?
O Glory cheaply bought! Come Death, come quickly;
Come thou, more lov'd than Curtius; haste to meet me.
The grim Man hears me. See! he comes; I feel him.
Farewel: I go in haste; with greater Joy,
Than love sick Virgins lose their name to Hymen.
Farewel for ever.

sp.speaker: Sp. Tar.
sp.l: Farewel my shame, and glory!—
Nature wou'd shew it self; it whispers me,
She was my Daughter; True, but she died bravely.
I ought not then to shed one tear, but triumph.
Take up the Body, Souldiers, as one of us;
For tho she were a Virgin, she was martial.
Such Obsequies as are to Hero's given,
Shall be my Daughters: A Maid of manly courage:
A Soul oppos'd to destiny: Her shame
Was Love and Life, Revenge and Death her fame.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: THis welcome news must sure restore her.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I doubt it not at all: Her late sleep too contributes.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Where not you present, Cloe, when Cornelia
Made the Relation to her?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: How did she receive it?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: As one of us would a surprizing Story,
When half a sleep: She started, blusht, then askt
A thousand little questions, to no purpose,
Then blush't again, and turn'd away her eyes,
As conscious and ashamed of her late weakness.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: These simptoms shew returning sense, tho slowly,
And by degrees, as harmless. Virgins wake
From pleasing dreams.—

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: O Portia! O my Cloe, witness all
What here Cornelia tells me. She sayes Hostilius,
She sayes my Sister, too? And not she only,
But Hostilius are coming hither.—

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: It is most true.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: Go you wou'd all deceive me: You tell me Heaven
Will come to me, and all the upper world
Stoop to a silly Girl. Fie on you all!
How can I think it? Go, you are all deceivers.

sp.speaker: Cot.
sp.l: Look, Madam, trust your eyes.—

sp.speaker: Hersi.
sp.l: Feliciana! O my long-mist Dear.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: O my Sister!

sp.speaker: Hersi.
sp.l: My haste to see my sweet Feliciana,
Transported me, and wou'd not let me rest,
Till thus I settle in her dear embrace.—
Why are you silent, sweetest! sure some vast joy
Stifles her words.— What does this mean, Cornelia?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: O Madam, since you went, all her fair senses
Have been as absent, as your self, and her
Much loved Hostilius.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: No wonder then the way being thus disturb'd,
If her returning Wits appear to wander.

sp.speaker: Hersi.
sp.l: I'le guide e'm right, for I have joyes in store,
Great, as her past affectons. Come with me
Sweet innocence! Fortune's not alwayes angry
She now is pleas'd again, and bids you too
Smilelike herself, the happy hour's arriv'd:
The happy hour, that gives your Sister means
To pay what she has stood so long engag'd for.
I'le make Hostilius yours: For I can give him.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: I dare not trust you.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: You must: You shall this once, and never after.
Hast, my Feliciana: Let us flie,
On the soft wings of Love, to meet Hostilius.

div.head: SCENE III. A Garden.
div.l: THis is the place, and this the time appointed.
As soon as I arriy'd back at the Pallace,—
These were her words.— I'le then and there said she.
Confer the dear reward I mention.—
What can that be? but what, it shou'd not be.
She knows, she knowes, I value no reward,
But only what, she shou'd not give, her Love.
O Romulus! my friend! how can I think,
That name, and yet wait here for his dishonour.—
Yet I am innocent,— I'le back again.
She is not here: Than why shou'd I expect,
And do so foul an action, in cold blood?
No, I will back again:— I cannot go.
Methinks I shou'd attend a Ladies motion,
Much more a Queens, a Goddess, such as Hersilia.
Deceitful Love! O thou false impostor!
O my my lost friendship! Lost! I will not lose it.
But one turn more, and I will, will go.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: Stand you all out of sight; there at that turning,
And when I call appear.— I see him yonder,
Pensive he walks, as if he fear'd to meet
What he expects. I know he thinks my Love,
The promised Recompence, for his past service,
I'le soon transfer his thoughts to the right object.
He sees me.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: Does not Hostilius wonder to what end
I meet him thus, and in a place so far
Removed from sight and interruption?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Not at all, Madam: Hersilia cannot have
A thought unworthy of her self, and Honour:
(Aside) What a soft charming look has she put on?
Oh I am ruin'd!—

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: I told you Sir, I knew,
Of a reward that I am sure will please you:
Tis Love, and such a Love you must not slight.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Ay: It is so: My fears, and my desires
Are joyn'd to make me wretched: I am lost:
Lost past recovery.
What Man can stand against such sweet temptation?

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: 'Tis from no Common beauty; but one adorn'd
With all the advantages of Birth and Fortune,
Young, witty, noble, innocent, and fair,
As the first smiles of Summer Mornings are:
Chearful as April Suns, fresh as the Spring.—

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: It must be she her self, the Character
Sutes with no other Woman.—

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Ha! my Hersilia, and Horsilius here
Alone too—

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: Such is the Lady that has loved you long,
Hostilius: She has loved you to excess,
But hitherto unknown; her flame has lasted
Silent and to her self, as Lamps in Tombs.—
I am amaz'd to see you thus unmoved.
Can you hear this Intelligence, from me too,
And give it no more welcome?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: What do I hear? What, do I see? I will
Not trust my senses, they are all deceitful
No, in despight of my own eye and ear,
I'le observe on: Down, down, rebellious thought.—
'Tis false, Hersilia cannot wrong me.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: These are too quick advances: And less than
Decent, Methinks, she's not so fair as lately.
A Cloud is drawing o're her eye, I see it.
Now love, where art thou? the Coward Boy's retiring.
Honour I am all thine.—
Madam, I must confess, it is a vast
Reward you offer for a little service.
So vast, and so surprizing is the offer,
I scarce have sense enough left to refuse it.
Had your words been less clear, I shou'd not then
Have dared to know their meaning; But now
They are so plain, I must not understand 'em.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: I am o'rejoy'd to find him answer thus.
I see he thinks it is my Love I offer;
And by my conduct I have cur'd his phrenzy,
Extinguisht all the Rebel flame for me,
And made him capable of a new passion.
— And can you then refuse the Love I bring you?
Can you, Hostilius, when Hersilia sayes
Love and be happy, slight the precious news?
How have I been deceiv'd? 'Twas falsly said,
Hostilius honour'd, loved, adored Hersilia,
Since she commends a Ladies Passion to him?
And yet Hostilius stands as unconcern'd.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I'le hear no more: My patience is abused.
False, False Hersilia.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: My Lord, I have been making Love here.—

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: And can you own it too? But you 're already
Too much dissembled. O that I had died
By Tatius juster sentence; not lived to see
His Daughter, thus much worse than kill me.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: Nay, than 'tis time to disabuse you both—
Feliciana: Sister! Where are you?
Look, Hostilius—
This is the Lady, for whose sake I wo you.
Has not my Character, short of her Beauty,
Wrong'd her, by an imperfect commendation?
Take her, brave Man, and here bestow that love,
Which err'd to me; nor was your Error lost,
When you imagin'd I could wrong my Lord
But in a thought: 'Twas all designed for this.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: How base do I appear! Poor, and unworthy;
And how divine Hersilia: yet I am pleased.
Take from my Character ye Gods: Take, take,
Yet more, and add it all to hers; for she
Alone merits to be; nay is perfection.
Let after Ages copy from Hersilia,
When they wou'd learn what's good, or chaste, or noble.
But let the name of Romulus be odious,
Since he could wrong her love by base suspition.
Can you forgive?— O I want assurance
To ask. So much injustice you ought not,
You must not pardon. Such a Crime as mine
Exceeds, if it were possible, your Goodness.—

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: O hold, or I shall doubt with better cause
Your love, than you did mine. Can Romulus
Be kind to me, and yet forbid my kindness?
You speak of pardon, where you ne're offended.
My dearest Lord, I'm pleas'd at your suspicion.
If (as th'appearance was) you had not been moved,
Sure you had loved me less.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: O wondrous goodness! Miracle of women.
Can you still love me?

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: My life, I can, I doe!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: But, Madam, what must I return, for this dear blessing?
I'm so confounded with the mighty favour,
I know not where first to bestow my thanks;
To my sweet Mistress, here, who thought me worthy,
Or to your self, who form'd my erring heart,
For such a Heaven,

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: Pay 'em to her: Only her love deserves them.
See, Sir, her blushes keep her speechless; but
That very silence tells you, she merits more
Than you can pay her.—

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: To, Armes, to Armes: O! quick, or Rome is lost.
The Sabines enter at Port Ianualis
Led on by Tatius: Curtius too half desperate,
Since his late loss, fights now with double Courage.
The Guards give ground apace, and they are neer
Possest of all that Quarter.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: A truce with Love Hostilius, we are call'd
To bolder actions.—

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: — Were all their Army present
I have no power to stir, till thus I pay,
At this soft shrine of Love and innocence
My first Devotions.
From this dear touch, I take new life, new Love,
And thus inspir'd to certain conquest move.

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: He's gone: while he was here I had no power
To speak, to move, or any thing but blush.
My overflowing joy met every thought,
And choak'd my words e're they could reach my tongue.
My fears, my fears, now give me Elocution.
O I shall lose your Present Sister. In vain,
You gave me the brave Man: The cruel Sabines
Will rob me of Hostilius.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: Why shou'd you fear
Success? have not I made a greater venture,
My Soul, my Romulus, my All I hazard
In this ingagement.— But if I hazard all
Why stand I here? Can I be safe, when he,
My better self's in danger? Cloe, run,
Gather the Sabine Women in a body:
Bid 'em all meet with speed at Iuno's Temple.—

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: What means my Sister?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I feel unusual joy shoot through my heart:
Something within me whispers, that as I
First caused this war, so it is I must end it.
Swell noble thought, That I may something do
Worthy a Roman Wife, and Sabine Daughter.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: Be happy Madam: Heaven declares for Rome.
The Gods fight for us. When your Romulus
Found his men flying, and that no perswasions,
Nor threats, nor his example cou'd prevail,
To stay the Coward Fugitives, to all
His friends above, the pious Roman calls,
And vows a Temple in the place to Iove.
Behold a Miracle! they, who but now
Fled as so many Hares, turn on the sudden.—

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: I'm seised with joy and wonder.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.l: But this is, Madam, wonderful indeed.
While the prevailing Sabines bore all before 'em,
Pursuing fiercely along by Ianus Temple,
A stream of Sulphur flow'd more fiercely on 'em,
From the offended God: Drowning and burning them,
But giving us more time and means to rally.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: Shall the two ever jarring Elements
Of Fire and Water, lay by their enmity,
Uniting both their powers for Rome, while I,
The Wife of Romulus, stand unconcern'd?
No, I will lose my Nature too; cast off
The fears of Woman, and with a Troop
Of my own Sex, confront the thickest danger.
But stay you here, my sweet Feliciana,
Thy years are much unfit for such a hazard.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Unkind Hersilia! Why shou'd you under-rate
My love, and think it less than yours?
Young as I am, I dare as much as you.
For love and my Hostilius, I am all fire:
And yet I durst not go, were not he there;
But to meet him, tho in a Grave, I dare.

div.head: SCENE Ult. The Scene draws, and discovers the Romans and Sabines ready to engage. Drums and Trumpets.
div.stage: Romulus, Hostilius, Tatius and Curtius come forward.

sp.speaker: Tat.
sp.l: Forbear a while.— Since, Romulus, we meet
So opportunely, let us two, who have
The chief concern in this unhappy War,
Decide the quarrel singly. Why shou'd we
Profusely cast away a thousand lives
Harmless and unconcern'd? when we may better
Stake all th'event of war on our own heads.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: The offer's just and noble: I accept it.

sp.speaker: Tat.
sp.l: Give your command then, to your Roman party,
As I to mine (who I 'm sure will obey me)
That they remain spectators only, and
Both sides yeild to him that conquers.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Sure Tatius, never heard Hostilius named.
Am I soe great a stranger, to your ear?
Or has report, ne're mentioned the strict friendship.
With which the God like Romulus has graced me.
'Tis time you know it now, if yet you have not.
I cannot see my King engaged,
And I unactive.—

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: — Nor I my General.
Once more, Hostilius, fortune presents my sword
To oppose yours; sure now we may decide
What late we left imperfect.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: With as much joy as absent Lovers meet.

sp.speaker: Tarp.
sp.l: Is there not yet one Sabine more that dare
Contest with me the Justice of this War?
Must I be so unhappy to stand idle,
A poor Spectator of brave deeds, and want
One noble Enemy among so many?

div.stage: [Two or three Sabines are coming forward io answer.

sp.speaker: Tat.
sp.l: Retire and keep your places.— You see Tarpeius
Here are enow, that strive for the like honour;
But since your King agrees to fight me single,
I'le have no more engaged than are already:
Hostilius has indeed put in no common claim.
Or else he too had been refused.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Be not displeased, thou brave and worthy Roman.
'Tis sit I leave one friend alive, to tell
Posterity, how much I die Hersilia's:
How much my heart abhorr'd to live,
Unless in her: How my last sillable was her's,
And how my Soul flew in a trembling sigh
Up with her name to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Tat.
sp.l: We lose too many minutes; Roman advance,
And meet me as a Foe implacable.
Respect me not, as Father to Hersilia,
Rather than so, I cancel all Relation,
Quit my Alliance, and disown my blood.

div.stage: Enter Hersilia, Feliciana, and other Women, who all run in between 'em.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: Do,— kill us first, and then your selves. Add this
To the great List of all your Glorious Acts,
That you have Murdered all these unarm'd Women:
Where am I now arriv'd? Is that my Father?
He is or shou'd be: This I'me sure's my Husband.—

sp.speaker: Feli.
sp.l: And this to me more dear, than thousand Husbands.
I'le be Hostilius shield, weak as I am,
He that wounds him must do it through my breast.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: Sir,

sp.speaker: Tat.
sp.l: Woman away.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: Have I no nearer Name?

sp.speaker: Tat.
sp.l: Hersilia,—

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: Still that has too much distance: methinks
I hear my Mothers Soul, from her blest seat
Of rest, call out and say, I am your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Tat.
sp.l: You were; till disobedient Love blotted that name,
And render'd all my blood degenerate,

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: — My Lord,—

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: My better life! Retire Hersilia.
O do not thus expose to the blind Sword,
A life inestimable: To see you bleed
Wou'd kill my very Soul. Shou'd I lose you
I lose a thousand lives, a thousand worlds.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: Perish a thousand Worlds, before I see
My Father kill my Husband; He my Father.
You both devide my Duty: I live in both,
And die in either: why shou'd you then endeavor?
To murder me twice over in your selves.
I had rather once in my own person die
Than twice in yours: Begin, begin with me:
Take my life he that pleases; take it freely.
But spare each other.—

sp.speaker: Tat.
sp.l: These, Romulus, are your security:
I'le draw my Party off; some other time
We'll find an hour more masculine and noble,
When we may act like men, not talk to women.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: O stay; for to part thus has something in't
Worse than my present fears. O hear me Sabines!
Hear me you noble Romans! If for my sake
This war was first begun, why for my sake
May it not now be ended? Am I Hersilia?
Have I a Father and a Husband here,
And yet want interest to mediate with you?
Sure Nature cannot be so far defective;
I know my Father cannot be obdurate;
I know it by my self; if he were cruel
I could not be compassionate and kind:
No, he was never cruel; 'twas but dissimulation.
When lately he condemn'd my Lord and I.

sp.speaker: Tat.
sp.l: Thus far 'tis true, tho I condemn'd you justly,
I never meant the threatned Execution.
Curtius knows it,—
But what is that to this? We now meet equal,
And I to vindicate my Right, and Honour.
Hersilia, give us way; when Kings dispute,
Swords are their Arguments, Force their perswasion.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: No, make your way to him through me.— Yet hold,
Your Sword is needless, I feel a sharper weapon;
The thought of your unkindness kills me surer.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: O stay fair Soul! If but one minute longer,
Stay but to take me with you— No, she's gone!
Look back Hersilia, I shall soon o're take you.

div.stage: [Offers to fall on his Sword. Hostilius holds him. Hersilia recovers.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: What pleasing voice unkindly calls me back
From the eternal rest of injur'd Lovers?
Sure 'tis my Lord; it must, it must be he;
No Tongue but his can draw Souls from Heaven.

sp.speaker: Tat.
sp.l: I am o'recome. He that can see such Love
And yet not melt, is not a Man but Devil.
I yield, O Divine power of Love,
That can subdue a fury such as mine!
Be happy in each other, best of Lovers,
My Daughter, and my Son! I'm doubly blest;
Since now in knowing you, I know my blessing.—
Sheath all your Swords: give the Command abroad,
That like me, each embrace his Enemy.

sp.speaker: Hers.
sp.l: O happy change,

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Blest be Hersilia, ever!
Since to her Piety we owe this change.
Never was War so ended!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Yet one more blessing, Sir, and we are all happy.
Our hearts are both united: We only want
Your favour to compleat a Glorious Hymen.

sp.speaker: Tat.
sp.l: This is my second comfort. Take her Hostilius,
For you deserve her. Thou second Romulus!
Live, Love, and be as happy as the first.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Tarpeius you alone know my dishonour.
My false, base, Treason, and the Love that caused it:
My mind is now reform'd: I am no more,
Rival to Romulus, but his admirer.
When I behold his flame my own expires,
As brighter Suns put out the lesser fires.
As you are Noble, then conceal my shame,
For I repent it much.—
And I am now prepar'd by future kindness
To pay off all that mighty Debt of Love,
Which I have too long ow'd to your much injured Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sp. Tarp.
sp.l: Your Debts discharged, Sabinus, and hers already paid
To Nature: Tarpeia is no more.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Tarpeia dead? Forbid it Heaven!

sp.speaker: Sp. Tarp.
sp.l: Unable to endure the sense of such dishonour
As her unhappy Love contracted, by her own hand
She washt the spots of Fame in her own blood.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Ah Noble Maid! too brave, and too unhappy!
Heroes and Demy-Gods shall Celebrate Tarpeia.
Queens when they'd Name a Maid of mighty Courage,
And vindicate their Sex above the Male,
Will say Tarpeia: But most the hapless Lover,
When he complains of Cross and Cruel Stars,
Shall weeping mention her sad fate and call it his.

sp.speaker: Sp. Tarp.
sp.l: Curtius no more: Let us forget our sorrows.
We injure much our Countries publick Joy:
No Passion now shou'd Raign, but Love and Triumph.

sp.speaker: Tat.
sp.l: Romans and Sabines are no longer two,
But the same Nation, now: Where such a Love
Has shew'd the way to Rome, we must all follow.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Renown'd for ever be this day and place:
Here for all Ages, let the Roman Tribes,
Fix their Comitium, for more solemn meetings.
Here every year let all the blooming Youth,
And tender Virgins, of our now own people,
In Songs and Revels Celebrate this day:
And as a Monument of the late wonder,
Let Ianus Temple, ever open stand
When Rome has War, the God for us will fally.
Happy the Nuptials, when two Kingdomes Wed:
Empire and Crowns spring from that Marriage Bed.

div.head: EPILOGUE Writ By Mrs. A. Behn.
div.l: FAir Ladies, pitty an unhappy Maid,
By Fortune, and by faithless Love betray'd.
Innocent once— I scarce knew how to sin,
Till that unlucky Devil entring in,
Did all my Honour, all my Faith undo:
Love! like Ambition, makes us Rebels too:
And of all Treasons, mine was most accurst;
Rebelling 'gainst a King and Father first.
A Sin, which Heav'n nor Man can e're forgive;
Nor could I Act it with the face to live.
My Dagger did my Honours cause redress;
But oh! my blushing Ghost must needs confess,
Had my young Charming Lover faithful been,
I fear I'd dy'd with unrepented Sin.
There's nothing can my Reputation save
With all the True, the Loyal and the Brave;
Not my Remorse, or Death, can expiate
With them a Treason 'gainst the KING and State.
Some Love-sick Maid perhaps, now I am gone,
(Raging with Love, and by that Love undone;)
May form some little Argument for me,
T' excuse m' Ingratitude and Treachery.
Some of the Sparks too, that infect the Pit,
(Whose Honesty is equal to their Wit,
And think Rebellion but a petty Crime,
Can turn to all sides Int'rest does incline,)
May cry" I gad I think the Wench is wise;
" Had it prov'd Lucky, twas, the way to rise.
" She had a Roman Spirit, that disdains
" Dull Loyalty, and the yoke of Sovereigns.
" A Pox of Fathers, and Reproach to come;
" She was the first and Noblest Whig of Rome.
But may that Ghost in quiet never rest,
Who thinks it self with Traytors Praises blest.
